testimony.name: Theresa Kaplan
key_points: Support for City of Yes to increase housing affordability and availability
Personal struggle with rising rental prices in the neighborhood
Contrast between high investment in brownstone renovations and limited housing stock increase due to outdated zoning policies
Benefits of allowing people to remain in their neighborhoods as housing needs change
Creating housing that fits residents rather than selecting residents who fit the housing
Fostering stable communities through diverse housing options

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Speaking more broadly, I am particularly excited about the transit oriented development proposal.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly mentions the transit-oriented development proposal, indicating that the speaker is discussing this element of the City of Yes for Housing Opportunity initiative.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Transit oriented development, in particular small apartment buildings scaled for low density neighborhoods, allows people to remain in their neighborhoods even as their housing needs change.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote elaborates on the transit-oriented development proposal, discussing how it would allow for small apartment buildings in low-density areas near transit, which aligns with the initiative's goal of allowing 3-5 story apartment buildings within a half-mile of public transit.
